awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Antarctic Automatic Weather Station Program 2016-2019
awd_abstract_narration:
The Antarctic Automatic Weather Station (AWS) network is the most extensive ground meteorological network in the Antarctic, approaching its 30th year at several of its installations. Its prime focus as a long term observational record is to measure the near surface weather and climatology of the Antarctic atmosphere. AWS stations measure air-temperature, pressure, wind speed and direction at a nominal surface height of ~ 2-3m. Other parameters such as relative humidity and snow accumulation may also be taken. Observational data from the AWS are collected via Iridium network, or DCS Argos aboard either NOAA or MetOp polar orbiting satellites and thus made available in near real time to operational and synoptic weather forecasters. The surface observations from the AAWS network are important records for recent climate change and meteorological processes. The surface observations from the AAWS network are also used operationally, and in the planning of field work. The surface observations made from the AAWS network have been used to check on satellite and remote sensing observations.

This project proposes to use the surface conditions observed by the AWS network to determine how large-scale modes of climate variability impact Antarctic weather and climate, how the surface observations from the AWS network are linked to surface layer and boundary layer processes, and to quantify the impact of snowfall and blowing snow events. Specifically, this project proposes to improve our understanding of the processes that lead to unusual weather events and how these events are related to large-scale modes of climate variability. This project will fill a gap in knowledge of snowfall distribution, and distinguishing between snowfall and blowing snow events using a suite of precipitation sensors near McMurdo Station.

por.por_cntn:
AWS Network

The foundation of this project is the care of the Antarctic Automatic Weather Station (AWS) network through maintenance and repair work. Roughly 90 site visits were accomplished over the core 4 years of the project. This averages to roughly 22 sites visited per year which is more than one third of the AWS network of 57 AWS locations. Visiting most of the network once every 3 years is a successful objective met by this project. Keeping the AWS network operating provides meteorological observations in support of weather forecast operations, weather research, climate investigations, and educational outreach.

The data measured at the AWS sites is quality controlled (QC) via a computer-human process. These QC datasets are reliably used in any application. A significant effort has been put into quality controlling historical datasets in a gap in the mid to late 2000s. 

The information about the AWS network is now being cataloged with the World Meteorological Organizations (WMO) Observing System Capability Analysis and Review Tool (OSCAR). This very extensive information catalog will house the main AWS station information for all to reference.

Research

Main research on this project included a test of a precipitation/blowing snow detection sensor at Alexander Tall Tower AWS. A test was also conducted during this project to capture improved temperature observations. Both of these engineering tests are examples of extending the capabilities of the AWS platform in the harsh Antarctic environment.

Project participants published science literature, many in collaboration with external partners, with the use of the observations from the AWS network. Specifically, the observations have informed the world via the yearly State of the Climate report published by the American Meteorological Society.

Outreach

Educational outreach is a central value to the AWS project and our efforts are multifaceted. One element is our engagement with the PolarTREC program. During this project we have worked with three PolarTREC teachers (middle and high schools from across the US - Texas, Arkansas, and Pennsylvania), deploying two teacher to Antarctica with the AWS team. Over the life of this project, engagement with students and the general public has been woven into our routine activities. Our outreach efforts have also included interviews with broadcast media (e.g. radio, TV, etc.).

Data Distribution

The observations from the AWS network are distributed to the Antarctic and the global communities. Work on offering the data via a database was explored, and is now incorporated into a formal data repository as a part of the Antarctic Meteorological Research and Data Center. This repository has an even broader impact, enabling anyone easy access to the AWS observations.
